title: Is it wrong to use 'as if' twice in the same sentence, like this, 'He felt as if something was trying to warn him, as if there was an actual presence around him.', or is there a more practical way to write this? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not necessarily wrong grammatically. It is, however, quite clunky and awkward. It doesn’t flow. It isn’t graceful. Instead of changing one of the “as if”s to an “as though,” I’d scrap the sentence and rewrite it. He felt a subliminal presence, something not quite tangible, trying to warn him. He felt something trying to warn him—something like a presence, without form or shape. He felt a warning from the air, as if from some unseen presence hovering just at the edge of his awareness.

The only detraction is punctuation; the two “as if” clauses should have been set apart by a dash character— He felt as if something was trying to warn him—as if there were an actual presence around him." . . . .dash because the sense being conveyed is a parenthetical association between the two clauses . . . and not a replication as would be indicated not by comma but by semicolon. Similarly, there would be no error for the “as if’s” to be formatted as a repetitive list. . . . as if something was . . . ; as if there were . . . .
